crops.description: One of the best pasture grasses in India, each plant producing a dense mass of fine stems a foot or more high. It produces need in great abundance.

(Cenekrus granularis L., 1771, Mantisa Plantarum, p 575.) The seeds of this grass were received under the name Meniauris granuleris Swartz, 1738 (Nova Genera et Species Plantarum, p. 25), which is based on Cencheus granuleris 1 .. However, Linnaeus had published in 1771 (Mantina Plantarum, pp. 161, 300) the generic name Mamisuris with one species Af. myurus, which is not now considered to be congeneric with Cenekrus granuleris L., thus invalidating the use of the generic name Mamisuris for the latter species. This fact was recognized by Kuntze, who proposed foe Cenekeus granmlerix La. the name Harkelochloa (Revisão Generum Plantaruan, 1891, pt. 2, p. 776). However, in 1830, Seringe (Bulletin Botanique, vol. 1. p. 219) had published the generic name Rytilix, citing " Manicuris granularis et myurus Auct." and listing one species, R. glanduloss. While there is no description, the facts that M. granularis was cited first, that the name R, glandulost is proposed and that "giandulosa" and "granularis" are considered to refer to the same plant characteristic, lead one to consider Maniauris granularis to be the type of the genus Rytilix.
Said to be one of the best pasture legumes in India.
A tall, erect species being tested for hay at Kirki.
A creeping species abundant in sorghum, etc., at Kirki. The green pods are caten by boys.

(Ophiuros corymbosus (L. L.) Gaertn. f. In publishing the genus Ophiuros, Gaertner cited Rottboellia boellia Linn, and Jums,., and described and figured two species, Under the first, O. incurvat a, are cited the descriptions of Aegilops incurvata L, and Rottboellia incurrala L. f. Under the second. O. corymbosa, are cited the descriptions of Argilopa exaltata L. and Rottboellia corymbosa L., f., the latter of which is based on Argilopa exaltata, the specific name being changed because of Rottboellia eralista I. t. appearing earlier on the same page of the Supplementum (1781, p. 114). The generic characterization covers both grasses; but the first species is more completely described, Gaertner not having any fertile flowers of the second, of which he remarks that it might prove to be very closely related to Digitaria if the flowers were better known, It would therefore be necessary to consider the first species, O. incurrota, as the type of the genus Ophiuros, As Aegilops exaltata is not now considered to be congeneric with O. incurvala it must be referred to another genus. In 1829, Kunth (Revision des Graminées, vol. 1, p. 153) published the genus Mnesithea with one species, M. ferris, based on Rottboellia lorris Retzius. As this grass is considered to be congeneric with the species received as Ophiuros corymbosa, the latter is here placed in the genus Mnesithea, the earliest specific name, exaltata, being restored.
A prostrate legume abundant in the Dekkan, Said to be good fodder.

A large annual Panicum producing enormous panicles 12 to 18 inches long and nearly as broad. These panicles break off and drift over the country after the manner of tumbleweeds. The grass is considered fair forage.
A tall, rather coarse grass growing on comparatively low ground. It makes only fair forage.
A grass growing about Poona in more or less shaded places, especially where somewhat molat.
A grass abundant throughout northern and central India and considered excellent forage. Much of it is cut for hay.
Very similar to the preceding, but with much more slender stems.
Collected on wet banks, The leaves are like white clover and the scapes bear one or two bright-blue flowers.
A perennial grass forming a considerable element of the grammy meadows.
Probably variety Themeda roglei Hook. f. An abundant element of the gramny meadows of the Nilgiri Hills and considered good forage.
Locally abundant in the grassy meadows of the Nilgiri Hills.
Common in shady places in the Nilgiri Hills at 6,000 feet altitude.
